case_vignette: An 81-year-old man patient recently moved into an assisted living facility and presents today with itchy blisters in his axilla. He attributes these to a poor diet. He also complains that the nurse practitioner at the facility started him on 4 new medications, in addition to his existing prescriptions. On physical examination, tense axillary bullae are noted that do not rupture with light, gloved touch. On direct immunofluorescence, linear C3 and IgG deposits are seen along the basement membrane.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have itchy blisters in my underarm area.
Have you had these symptoms before?
No, this is the first time I'm experiencing this.
Have you recently traveled to a new area or come into contact with any new substances?
I recently moved into an assisted living facility.
Have you noticed any other symptoms such as fever, fatigue, or joint pain?
No, just the itchy blisters.
Have you had any recent injuries or cuts in the underarm area?
No, I haven't had any injuries or cuts there.
Have you noticed any changes in your skin color or texture in the underarm area?
The blisters are tense, but they don't burst when touched lightly.
Have you noticed any changes in your appetite or weight?
No, I haven't noticed any changes in my appetite or weight.
Have you noticed any changes in your mood or energy levels?
No, my mood and energy levels have been the same.
Have you noticed any changes in your sleep patterns?
No, my sleep patterns haven't changed.
Have you noticed any changes in your skin color or texture in other areas of your body?
No, just the blisters in my underarm area.
Have you noticed any changes in your skin color or texture in your family members?
No, my family members haven't had any skin changes.
Final Diagnosis: Contact Dermatitis.
